name: Portal
description: Portal™ is a new single player game from Valve. Set in the mysterious Aperture Science Laboratories, Portal has been called one of the most innovative new games on the horizon and will offer gamers hours of unique gameplay.
minimum_requirements: 1.7 GHz Processor, 512MB RAM, DirectX® 8.1 level Graphics Card (Requires support for SSE), Windows® 7 (32/64-bit)/Vista/XP, Mouse, Keyboard, Internet Connection Recommended: Pentium 4 processor (3.0GHz, or better), 1GB RAM, DirectX® 9 level Graphics Card, Windows® 7 (32/64-bit)/Vista/XP, Mouse, Keyboard, Internet Connection

reviews.review_text: 'The cake is a lie!'  It is, but Portal does not lie as it truly is a good game! While short, its puzzles make it an interesting game so much so that you'd immediately want to do a 2nd walkthrough. Also, there is a way to replay several of the so-called 'chambers' but in a more difficult version.  I'm not sure if this has mods like its sequel - nevertheless, it's worth completing this one before moving on to the next as the puzzles are even more difficult and diverse in Portal 2.  I like how the game has a background story while it would not be necessary, at all. It has an excellent antagonist in the form of an A.I. called GLaDOS.  Portal is a memorable experience and if you liked Half-Life you should pick up this Valve product, as well.  Oh, you didn't like Half-Life? Then, please go and have a cake. :)  PS: I'm not sure why I have zero hours logged for this game. Probably because the logging system was introduced after I completed Portal. In any case, my review is based on a gameplay time of roughly 15-20 hours.

Life was meaningless.  I had no purpose other than to continue my work, the only thing I had ever known. Work had been fun at first, and my boss had seemed nice and rather witty. However after some time, my boss began acting strange. It started with the lying. Then, my boss began to intentionally make my work dangerous. I survived, but only through quick thinking and a bit of luck.  Eventually the everyday grind of navigating my way through a neverending maze lost any appeal. My boss promised me cake when the job was completely done, but it wasn't worth it. I wished for something, anything, even death, that would rid me from this meaningless existence. I was tempted several times to walk infront of a turret or fall into the radioactive slime, but the pain these methods would bring seemed greater than the pain of a meaningless life, so I carried on.  Then one day, my boss had a surprise for me. He had brought me a Companion to assist me in my work. Or more specifically, an Aperature Science Weighted Companion Cube. At first, the Companion Cube assisted me with basic tasks which I nonetheless couldn't have done without it. We rounded a corner and came face to face with a ball of radioactive energy coming straight towards us.  I thought we were doomed, but then the Companion Cube jumped in front of me of its own accord and shielded me from certain death. My mouth dropped, as I imagined the pain the Cube must have been experiencing. My boss said something about 'symptoms of enrichment center testing' and 'perceiving inanimate objects as alive' but I paid no attention. I knew this was love. I knew this was real.  We continued on together for a while. The Cube was essential in completeing the task my boss had set for me. I tried talking to it, but I received no response. My boss then oddly informed me that the Companion Cube would never threaten to stab me (as if it would ever)...but more importantly he informed me that my Cube was mute. I felt a pang of sadness - not the selfish sadness one feels when they lose something, but the true sadness that is felt when empathizing with another being.  This revelation did not hamper my love for my Cube, my Companion, who had brought happiness and joy into my life, and who had selflessly endured pain to save me from death. After opening the final door which would lead to the elevator I had grown quite familiar with, our boss seemed to congratulate us on our new found compaionship. But then the bos said something which would change my life forever.  'However, [the Companion Cube] cannot accompany you for the rest of the test and, unfortunately, must be euthanized. Please escort your Companion Cube to the Aperture Science Emergency Intelligence Incinerator.'  I gasped in horror, looking across the room and seeing what I now realized must be the Incinerator. I fell to my knees, tears already streaming down my cheeks. I looked at my faithful Companion and proceeded to envelop it in my arms, determined to never let it go.  My boss continued on as if nothing was wrong. 'While it has been a faithful companion, your Companion Cube cannot accompany you through the rest of the test. If it could talk - and the Enrichment Center takes this opportunity to remind you that it cannot - it would tell you to go on without it because it would rather die in a fire than become a burden to you.'  'You could never be a burden to me!' I cried, and hugged my Companion Cube to my chest. But then I remembered. Although my boss had lied to be at one time, boss had since promised that he could no longer lie to me. I had to finish the testing, or else I would never get the Cake. And if the Cube couldn't come with me...didn't want to come with me...  I hugged it one last time then picked myself up off the floor. I walked slowly, hesitantly, toward the button that would open the incinerator. It took more willpower than I've ever needed to press it. Then I picked up my Companion and held it over the flames. Tears clouded my vision and my hands began to sweat uncontrollably, and not just from the heat. I held it there for what seemed like hours, just crying and admiring its beauty. But then I remember the Cake. And the Cube slipped from my hands.  'You euthanized your faithful Companion Cube more quickly than any test subject on record,' said my boss. 'Congratulations.'  11/10 would euthanize my Companion at the behest of my boss and all for a piece of cake again.

Portal is a unique puzzle game that will bend your mind in ways you never thought were possible. Although it is a short game, Portal will have you at the edge of your seat just waiting to see what crazy experiment GLaDOS has in store for you. Don't let the 3 hour main quest deprive you from buying this game. Portal is a enjoyable experience that I will come back to.   And yes you will be baked and then there will be cake.
Portal 1 is art. From the puzzles to the action, the game never fails to keep gamers happy. Though short, it is fun, innovative and creative. 10/10.

What else is there to say about Portal that hasn't already been said? It's fantastic and set a new precedent in gaming for this generation, showing that truly original concepts and fascinating story can trump good graphics and developer ownership.  Portal is astounding, and if you haven't played it, you really ought to. Though, make sure you have enough money spare for Portal 2; I guarantee you'll want to buy it as soona s you're done with Portal!  Nilesy

Portal is a first person puzzle series made by valve themselfs. So before we jump into this review we must praise our lord and savoir Gabe Newell.  There are many more good points than I expected there to be for an 7 year old game. The graphics are very good seeing as the age of the game, you could say it's graphically better than some current ones, no offense to developpers who don't focus on the graphical aspect. You get guided along the way with a robot voice called Glados and I must say she has more humor than the most game characters. For example she says 'Your test is almost over and after you'll be baked and then there will be cake.' The humour itself in this game was also very good, the boss level was very entertaining thanks to all the jokes it had and also the ending was pretty ironic because you'll be the one eating the cake. The ending song was actually amazing, I'm going to download it some time after writing this review. You can solve the puzzles using companion cubes or normal cubes and using your portal gun. The portal gun has two portals a blue one and an orange one and when you pass through one of them you come out of the other one. The controls are not that hard to understand, I barely changed any to my likings. The puzzles get harder each level but there are many useful checkpoints so it makes it not as bad when you die or get stuck.  There are a few minor things about this gem but this are just me noticing details while playing along. You can apparantly save when you are dead or about to respawn rather which is not that useful but I accidentally did that when playing. I was dying from drowning in a puzzle and I saved because I wanted to get back another day and it set my checkpoint to that death so it kept respawning me there. I sometime was doubting if I could portal on some wall or floors. There are three colors in this game, walls or floors rather said, those are black, beige and white. But since beige looks a lot like white you weren't sure if you could portal on it.   I'm doubting still why you are taking time reading this, still thankful though, and not buying this game. Even at full price at this moment it isn't a waste of money and don't mind the gametime as there are many bonusmaps and such which I didn't dig into (yet).
With around 9 minutes of gameplay it is a little on the short side, but that's okay.
One of the all-time great puzzle games. If you haven't played it yet, buy it now. I can't recommend it enough.

A truly unique experience (and I should know; I played this on the Xbox 360 at one point). More of a puzzle game than a first-person shooter, you use the portal gun to solve puzzles and find the exit for each testchamber. It introduced some innovative gameplay and one of the most memorable (and hilarious) villains in gaming.

After completing the game over four times, and doing the majority of things in Portal, I think I’m ready to review the game. So, Portal is a puzzle-platform game, developed by Valve, and as you cleverly-observed from the title ‘Portal’ there are… Portals, to help you pass each test chamber (best synopsis ever). Thus, I shall just jump straight into the review, which has been split into ‘different sections’ before giving my overall score and final opinions.    Story   –  The game has quite a simplistic story – the protagonist (Chell) has to navigate through a total of nineteen test-chambers with her Aperture Science Handheld Portal Device, or simply the ‘portal gun’. She is essentially a lab-rat for GLaDOS, who is an artificial intelligence that would guide and monitor the player. I won’t say any more than that, as it does get quite interesting by the end of the game. When I played through the game for the first time, it took me about three to four hours to complete with that time getting shorter and shorter as I knew how to get through each level, but there was never a point where I felt I paid far too much for the game, and I felt that the game’s length suited the value.     Gameplay   –  Obviously, throughout this game you use portals. At the start, you can shoot blue portals before obtaining the ability to shoot orange portals as well. This concept was clearly reused by the game ‘Narbacular Drop’; I believe the people who made that game also joined Valve in making Portal. This idea was interesting enough on its own, for a short game, but they added a few more mechanics such as the Weighted Companion Cube coming into play, or the usage of speed benefitting you in quite a few puzzles. And I liked how Portal applies physics to each of its puzzles, thus making each solution seem more logical (well as logical as portals existing anyway). Of course, it’s nowhere near as in-depth as a handful of gameplay mechanics that has been introduced in the game’s sequel – Portal 2, yet because of the game’s length and style, it holds on its own and I never felt bored by the simple gameplay.     Replayability   –  After completing the game, there are further options to lengthen your gameplay-time such as attempting the Advanced Maps, which are quite challenging and they are pretty much just harder versions of existing maps you’ve already done in the original game. There’s also Portal Challenges which involves you trying to beat a puzzle with the least amount of portals, least amount of steps or the fastest time possible (however as of yet, I haven’t tried this option). But aside of trying to claim achievements, finding Easter eggs, finding different ways to do the same puzzle or attempting speed-runs of the game (I managed to complete the game at around 2.1 hours on my last attempt), there is very little reason to actually run through the game beyond a second, or even third time. Yet, even then, I still feel like this game is worth your money and your play-time may reach five-seven hours, if you disregard achievement-hunting or other activities within the game.    Overall   –   This is a relatively shorter review, than to my first one, which suits the relatively shorter game (despite twenty hours of playtime) but honestly, this game must be acknowledged for its gameplay, its humour as well as its difficulty – as I have to say that the last four to six test-chambers do a good job of challenging you initially and there were fond moments, where I stopped and thought “Oh!!! That’s how you… …damn.”, after wasting length proportion dying and head-scratching. I can honestly say that this game was a memorable experience for me, when I first bought it a couple of months ago, and it is as fun and enjoyable as it is now, with me now having fond memories of many different sections within this game. I must recommend this game to all, as this is a great game with many great qualities and almost no flaws aside of length (which is not even a major problem for me). Therefore, I’m giving the game an   8/10   and I would highly recommend people to buy it whether you are ok with the price, or whether you wish to buy the Portal Bundle on sale (Portal 1 + 2) for a relatively cheap price, it’s up to you. Thanks for reading my review!    My Scoreboard   –  1/10 ---> 4/10 – Not worth it.  5/10 ---> 6/10 – Below Average/Mediocre.  7/10 – Above Average.    8/10 – Great.    9/10 ---> 10/10 – Outstanding + Must Own.

SPOILER ALERT: This game contains images of cake. Portal is an interesting combination of a puzzle and a story. The starting setup looks so simple, but the game builds up to its plot in an intriguing way. It drags you along and somehow manages to play with your feelings (it has succeeded to make me care for a cube :p2cube: ).   Pros: - Good story, built up very well - Funny, witty voice acting - Interesting puzzle challenges - Even the enemy turrets in this game are adorable :3 - Has cake  Cons: - Limited to the story line (does contain additional extras, but only a few) - That poor companion cube D':  All in all a great game! Curious? Don't wait any longer and start your duty as a test subject, complete the test chambers, and then there will be cake!  Rating: 8,5/10

It may be short, but boy is it sweet.  Portal  is one of those rare, perfect games.  Playing through  Portal , you'll be treated to delightfully subversive dark humor, which slowly gives way to a creepy, sinister atmosphere. the gameplay is rock-solid, too - challenging, but not unfair to the player. And without spoiling anything (like there's anyone who doesn't already know) I can tell you that Portal has one of the best video game characters this side of 2000.  Long after you've finished it, this game will stick with you.

Calling Portal a breath of fresh air is a huge understatement. Mixing puzzle gameplay, fantastic dialog, and the sadistic yet lovable frenemy GLaDOS, it is easily one of my favorite new IPs in years.   Though it starts out simple enough, Valve is quick to remind you of how incredibly smart and inovative they are. Portals begin being used in all sorts of ways I'd never have thought of, and yet it's never the least bit overwhelming or overly challenging. Solving the puzzles is great fun, but it's really the dialog that stands out. This is hands down some of the best writing I've heard in a video game, and it's delivery is marvelous.  Graphically it might not be the most technically impressive, but it's simple visual scheme is all it's own, and even the most mundane objects become memorable. To me this is absolutely a must play for each and everyone out there that calls themselves a gamer. It's charming, clever, and left me longing for more!

What can I say about this so famous game? Well, I guess it was amazing 10 years ago and I can see why people loved this one.   Unfortunately my expectations were maybe too high and so I was 'disappointed'. The game is pretty good but I was hoping for a masterpiece and as always happens with expectations I got screwed by my own unrealistic desire. Memo: Live the moment!   In fact if I think about the hours I spent playing this I can feel I actually had fun. The puzzles were not too hard, but the sense of wonder about how portals work was cool and I enjoyed that.   Too bad sometimes I had to fight the game itself (crates falling, setting portals were I wanted to, jumping). The other big issue was I got motion sickness eventually.   The last level was very cool (and way longer than I thougt) but the 'boss fight' was not excpetional (again expetations vs reality).   Anyway this is a very good game, as everybody knows so I would raccomand it to anyone who doesn't NEED to kill stuff to have fun  + Nice story + Very cool setting + Cool puzzles  - Maybe a little bit outdated - Controls (see description) - The portal sound effect is too loud for the music

This game is innovation and originality at it's best, and feels like nothing I've ever played before nor can I relate this game with another game. The puzzles are jam packed full of fun and figuring out how to finally complete that one level really does give you a sense of accomplishment. It's quite short but was great while it lasted and after completing the game you can test your skills on the bonus advanced and challenge maps which reuses the same levels but with added components to make the experience more challenging. Valve has once again made a great game and it only gets better for Portal from here on. ;)

What more can be said about Portal that hasn't already been said?   There have been other FPS games that had great puzzles within. For example, the physics engine that Valve built into Source were a big part of what made HL2 feel so fresh and new in 2004. It allowed for a new type of game puzzle - one based purely on mundane real-world puzzle solving. But Portal 2 takes that formula, and with one introduction (Portals), and one reduction (almost no adrenaline action), turns FPS into FPPP: First-person physics puzzler.   But the puzzles alone aren't what make Portal great. The pacing is perfect. The humor is dry and laugh-out-loud funny (tip: turn on the captions). But Portal's crowning achievement is its ability to make a player feel like a genius when he or she figures out the puzzles. The 'a ha' moments are a pure endorphine tidal wave.  If you haven't played Portal yet, what are you waiting for?

Portal review: Having already heard many good things about portal in the form and video reviews and word of mouth, I can confirm that you will not be disappointed. Portal is a challenging physics based game that shows off in the best possible way. Having said that the game isn't very long, having taken about 3:30 hours to finish it. I wasn't, however left unsatisfied. Portal was a simple yet challenging game that really gave me a sense of achievement having completed it. With the addition of bonus maps there is still plenty of work to be done after the main story line is finished. The story line itself is intricately with a lot of hidden secrets that's it is completely up to the player to find, adding another level to the game. All in all a fantastic idea coupled with a fantastic story line.. Making for a fantastic game  My rating: Length:8/10 Gameplay:10/10 All round enjoyment:10/10

Portal is 2007 First-person puzzle game developed by Valve in which you take the role of the main protagonist, Chell, as she tries to escape from Aperture Science Labs.  In this game, you, eventually, get the hold of the Aperture Science Handheld Portal Device aka Portal gun, which, obviously is used for creating portals. Levels are designed in a way that you have to think where to shoot the portals and get harder as the game progresses on. Further on, you will have to deal with turrets and think of clever ways to do that. Portals cannot be created on certain surfaces.   Portal's level design is brilliant and players will have to use the environment to their advantage. Story is also pretty good, and there is more of it in the second game. Last thing, there is cake.  The only downside I can think of is that its pretty short and can be completed in less than 3 hours, but I definitely recommend this game.

Portal is a game that gets you thinking with portals. You are being tested with portals and you have to solve various puzzles. It's a wonderful game, although it's a short one. It takes around an hour to complete.  The graphics don't need to be hyper realistic and actually aren't far off from the sequel of this game, 'Portal 2'. The puzzles aren't the hardest things in the world, and are also often based off of momentum, or to describe it simply,  'speedy thing goes in, speedy thing comes out.'  Though, the difficulty of the puzzles doesn't mean you won't die. Some puzzles will cause your death on the first try, but when you finally reach the moment when your mind figures out how to do this certain puzzle, the feeling is simply awesome. There are slight tricks that the robotic AI, GLaDOS says/does, one example is the promise of cake. She says  'You will be baked, and there will be cake' , which basically means that she will   attempt to kill you with fire.   Those tricks are nice and will cause you to listen to that part again to see if you heard it incorrectly or not.   Ultimately, this is quite an exceptional game.  Short version:  Nice gameplay. Good graphics. Awesome sensations, and neat twists. It's a tad bit short, bit is exceptionally grand.

Every line said in this masterpiece is well written.   Do yourself a favor by this game.  Why does an evil killer mastermind robot, have a shoe for orphans tool?

Portal was the first game I played on Steam, and what brought me back to PC gaming after a childhood of Nintendo. Its dark humor and soundtrack give it a distinct tone that can't be found even in Portal 2. The puzzles are fairly good, with the challenge mode versions requiring more thought.  The character of GLaDOS is what makes this game fantastic. The portals are an interesting puzzle mechanic, but without GLaDOS this game would have little character. Its spiritual ancestor, Narbacular Drop, is what this game would be without its story. And Narbacular Drop has almost nothing. The story arc is compelling and draws you into the game. Please get this game. It's worth it.

The more I played this game, the more I liked it. The more engaging it got. The more curious I became about what was going on in these test chambers. It only took me 4 or 5 hours to beat, yet somehow Valve managed to compress a truly remarkable amount of content into those hours. I didn't expect for a puzzle game to have such a fascinating story, which I won't tell you about for fear of ruining it. Nor did I anticipate the hilarious dialogue (or really, monologue), or the unique gameplay, or the unsettling atmosphere. Graphics are nothing special, but trust me when I say it doesn't matter: they don't bring down the game as a whole.  Before playing this game, I read on several websites that it's the best game of all time. I'm not sure I agree with that bold statement, but I was so unprecedently stunned by Portal, I can understand how someone could make a case for it.  Outstanding game that everyone who owns Steam, or just exists, should play. 9/10, think with portals!

Portal is an amazing game.  For starters, there's a very creepy vibe to it; you get the feeling that something isn't right. From the deserted observation decks above the testing areas, to the disembodied voice that tells you where to go, to the strangely disturbing writing on the walls ('the cake is a lie', 'she's watching you'), to the horrible, horrible turrets that talk soothingly to you as they launch you into the sweet embrace of death with their endless bullets, something is very wrong in the Aperture Laboratories Enrichment Center.  The gameplay is also really neat. As far as I can tell, Portal fits most neatly into the genre of 'first-person action-adventure puzzle-platformer shooter'. In other words, it really doesn't match any established genre of game around; and that alone is enough to give you bragging rights among gamers! (Well, it would have been enough in 2007, anyway. Now you're just late to the party, but as they say, better late than never.)  While it is definitely a short game, it's only $10 - seriously, you can't go wrong with it. Give it, oh, half an hour, and you'll be hooked. You'll probably buy Portal 2, too (there's a lot more to that one). Yes, there will be parts that you get stuck on (unless you watch a walkthrough). Just sleep on it. Trust me, in the morning you'll kick yourself and say 'How did I miss that?' All you have to do is think with portals. And the Weighted Companion Cube will be there, offering its silent support and a handy step up when all seems lost.   Oh, and one more thing. Remember, SHE LIES.

Great game! It is pretty easy, and the flexibility of the solutions to each level makes the timed challenge mode more complex. Also, the 'Transmission Recieved' achievement makes it more challenging for the overachievers. I have most of the radios, but I still have a headache or two to defeat still. The advanced test chambers demand better planning, timing, and nerve, and are relatively challenging... until you beat the first couple of levels. From there on, it gets easy until level 18, which puzzled me for a while on the first time playing through on the NORMAL version. The game is not very long. I wish it was longer. It needs to introduce the turrets earlier, if you ask me. If not, it needs to have more turrets and it needs to make removing them more challenging. Even the upgraded version of the turret seems almost harmless if you have a good rame rate. Even the final boss fight was simple and easy to defeat. I do not think difficulty was the point of this game. I think the main point of it was to just introduce players to the idea, concept, story, and format of the Portal series. All of these four things are artfully designed and are quite entertaining. I think the point of this game is to prepare players for the sequel, Portal 2. I have not played the sequel, so I do not know that for sure. If you're looking for just a fun and quick puzzle game that is relatively easy to master, then this is the game for you. If you are looking for more action in your gameplay, this may not be the game for you. I am one of those people, but I still enjoyed, enjoy, and will enjoy this game for a very long time. I think everyone can and should do the same, if they have the right mindset.

Portal is a fast paced, great game with an unpredictable storyline full of awesome twists, to the extent of false foreshadowing:  Test Centre -> Partygoing -> Escape + Rebellion  The visuals also complement the storyline, from the clean, crisp test chambers to the rusty metal of the facility's skeleton.  However, this game is a plot-motivated game and upon completing the storyline once or even twice, the player loses interest to play as there is nothing left to discover except playing the fun levels again. That's why users play the game for a significantly shorter duration than other games such as Team Fortress 2  Granted, this game is amazingly great in conceptual and perceptive aspects, with awesome graphics and mechanics, but it's a one-time thing. May not be worth a buy if you plan to get a game that you can play forever, so take my advice:  Wait for the sale

Portal is one of the most creative and hilarious series of the last 10 years. For 10 bucks, you get a game that I consider to be one of my favorites ever.    Though the first Portal is not as long as the second Portal, it is still incredibly detailed. To compensate for the short 3-4 hour story mode, you can have a go at more difficult versions of the different puzzle rooms that you encountered in the story mode. You can also do timed levels.   I confess that Portal 2 is in my estimation, a better game. However, Portal 1 is a great introduction to the world of Aperture. It is no doubt worth 10 dollars and is a work of art in a diminutive fashion.       Pros: Awesome story    It is funny and charming   There are options for more gameplay after the initial story   10 bucks for this game is a steal   If you like it, you can have 9 more hours with Portal 2's story and even more with mods and   multiplayer (on Portal 2)     Cons: A little short   No multiplayer

Now you're thinking with Steam- wait, what? Isn't this Portal?  Sorry, I was confusing this game with Codename: S.T.E.A.M. (a game which I do not own and do not care about).  Anyway, Portal is a cool-guy standalone game by Valve, obviously. Where were you when this game came out? Probably in your basement waiting for Half-Life 2: Episode Two (I don't know when that game came out, so maybe you were in your basement waiting for Half-Life 3, I don't know). This game was released all the way back in 2007, and for some reason I bought it seven years later when I already had and played the sequel.  Portal's gameplay is nothing like we've ever seen before, something that has never been done before. It uses portals, NO DUR! It's got cool puzzles and cool mechanics, nothing more to say. The mechanics are innovative and easy to learn. The Portal Gun is the center object of the game, if you've seen the trailer you probably know what it does. Go in one portal, come out the other and move it around with the gun it come from (BRING IT AROOUUND TOWN SQUIDWARD).  The story is a bit under wraps, it's kind of hard to notice if you don't pay much attention to it. This game does have a somewhat noticable story, but you'll be focusing too much on the puzzles to notice (look for the Easter eggs, bro!).  The game, to be honest, is short. About 18 maps in total (as in maps I don't mean test chambers/levels, I mean actual Source maps). The game is very fun though, I'll tell you that.  This game started the very trend that Valve always goes through when creating video games: Make a game, make an awesome sequel to that game, stop, and make every person that played and liked that game ticked off and die of hype.   The only criticism I have with Portal is the short number of mechanics and the game being short in general. But all in all, Portal is a very fun game. In case you didn't know, this game has WAY less mechanics than Portal 2 does.  Portal is very, very cool. It got an awesome sequel, a few mods both for that sequel and this game itself, and an ever-growing workshop for its sequel. But it just needs a little something, let me tell you what it is: ANOTHER SEQUEL. HEY VALVE, CAN YOU HEAR ME SCREAMING AT YOU, DEMANDING THAT YOU MAKE A PORTAL 3?! Probably not, it's not like you'd care or anything.  Thank you for reading this somewhat short review on Portal. Have a nice day, and thank you for flying with American Airlines. PEACE OUT!   9.0/10   YEAH SCIENCE!
Wow! This game was awesome 12 out of 10 I don't want to say what happens at the end but I didnt see it coming

I'm a big Portal fan; I had already played this game a fair amount before buying the Steam version and cannot recommend it enough. For those who have never played a Portal game, I recommend starting with this one before playing Portal 2.  This is an all-puzzle game where you solve puzzles by utilizing portals you lay yourself. The thing that was so cool about this game when I first saw it is that not only can you shoot the portals wherever you want, but the game actually renders what's on the other side of the portal. You don't just walk up to the portal and just magically get spawned where the other portal is. You actually walk through it.  Plot: You are a human test subject being held captive in an abandoned test facility. The only one left in the facility is the AI that controls it all, and forces you to continue her 'tests.' Your greatest ally is the portal gun, a 'gun' that shoots portals onto certain surfaces.  Pros: +Great sense of humor +Engaging puzzles +Sense of mystery and intrigue, despite the humor +Perfectly paced +Bonus puzzles and challenges to work on after beating the game +In-game developer commentary available  Cons: None  If it isn't obvious from the trailer, this game is controlled like an FPS.  The game will take less than four hours to beat, but I don't list that as a con, because to my knowledge Valve has always sold this game at a reduced price compared to a full AAA game. This game really is an experience to play. It is one of my all-time favorites and comes with my highest recommendation.

To be Honest, this 'game' is not really a game. Its a major set up for Portal 2. This is the introduction into the Half Life Universe and the Portal world, if you've never played many VALVe Games. This game starts off easy, with nothing but you a test subject called Chell. GLaDOS is planning to test your skills assuring you that cake will be your reward for testing. GLaDOS took over the Aperture Science Center as you learn throughout the game, and flooded the place with a neurotoxin, any survivors and she's use them as test subjects. As you progress through the levels, the puzzles get harder, but are not too hard. You'll need a (Drum Roll Please!.......) A whole 2 Hours to FInish it. Yeah, its short. But this game is the backbone to Portal 2. Highly Recommend this game, but suggest playing Portal 2 once you've played this.  9.72/10

I recently purchased Portal 1 & 2 through a bundle sale and I have to say I'm incredibly glad I did!  I personally prefer puzzle games that challenge me, and make me utilize objects or logistics in order to progress. This game does that and then some. It bends the laws of physics in a brilliant (and not-too-confusing) way and even throws in some cheeky humor. There are times when you can't figure out how to get past an area for the life of you, but juuuust before you chuck your computer through a window, you figure it out and feel the sweet satisfaction as you move on to the next level.  Even though Portal is a short game (I beat it in 5 hours my first time round), it is definitely worth playing. Especially to see the ending. The first time I got Portal was on the console version of the Orange Box. And I must say just like on the PC version, the game is still simply amazing. Instead of giving you the story right then and there. The game builds it up, not a whole lot is known, but eventually the pieces will fall into place in Portal 2.  Unlike the Half Life series where action-adventure mixed with science fiction and horror dominate the games. Portal is famously known for it's puzzles, simple yet challenging puzzles. Some puzzles might be obvious but other times it 'might' be obvious and then GLaDOS pulls a troll on you and you have to think more and more. If you thought rage quitting at Dark Souls was a thing. Try rage quitting at something so simple, a child could beat this game. And yes, there are many players in the past, and present who still get frustrated with some of the puzzles.   The game offers developer commentary (which I highly recommend). The game also has challenge puzzles and advance test chambers for you to play on. There are easter eggs in this game as well. Not obvious so be aware at all times. Lastly, GLaDOS for an AI entity has never been more amazing than any other AI entity in video game history. Her witty sarcasm attitude towards you in either serious or playful banter makes the game much more enjoyable.   I highly recommend this game to any and all puzzle fans. This one is surely for you.  Oh and the cake is a lie ;)

After finishing this game, I wanted cake.   I went to our local bakery to buy some cake. They said my order would be ready in about an hour.   So I come back an hour later, eager to eat my double chocolate cake. I couldn't wait to get home, open the box and enjoy that fat slice of cake.  So I go home, and I have a ritual of opening the box and closing my eyes and taking a small scoop of the frosting. But when I tasted it, it didn't taste the way I wanted to. In fact, it didn't taste like chocolate at all.  I opened my eyes, and saw an abomination. They had given me VANILLA cake.    11/10 The cake was a lie.

This game is a classic, even though i never played it before now, it is referenced in so much and has so many tribute videos, art, webcomics, etc. Needless to say that my exceptations were high when i started it and in most cases expectations are never fulfilled. Not with this game. It is simply in its own class of greatnes. It is one of those games you must have played. The concept is simple and effective, it's a FPP (First Person Puzzler) and while the puzzles are not that hard, you do need to stop and think about them once in a while, which makes it just all more compelling (whats the fun when there is no challenge, right?). Is it all good then? No, there are some lesser points to the game. First, it is really short and over before you know it. Second, some of the puzzles require this second perfect timing or pixel perfect jumping to complete and that can be frustrating sometimes (or perhaps i didn't solve them right?).

No cakewalk this one  This is one clever game. The concept is simple but brilliant: you’re trapped in the labs of Aperture Science and you have to get out. To assist you you’re given a portal gun. The gun opens doorways in almost any surface. Once you have full control of the gun you can create blue and amber portals. Step into the blue one and you emerge from the amber one, step into the amber one and you emerge from the blue one. By positioning the portals in certain ways you can step, jump, or fall huge distances. You can also use them to redirect lasers and bullets, which you must do in order to stay alive. All through your efforts to escape you’re teased and goaded by GLaDoS, the AI that runs the lab. As with all Valve games the writing is excellent, with GLaDoS delivering some perfectly-pitched lines (and a cute little song at the end). Each challenge is more difficult than the last but none is so frustrating as to annoy, and all are satisfying when solved. My only criticism is that the maps lack variety as you travel from one austere lab to another, or from one utility area to another (this appears to have been addressed in Portal 2, which offers a wider range of environments). All-in-all this is one of the most imaginative games I’ve ever encountered. Check out the Orange Box though, because this offers the excellent Half-Life 2 games and Portal as a bundle and is great value.  4/5

Friends, delegates and fellow Americans: I humbly and gratefully accept your nomination for the presidency of the United States. Story Continued Below Together, we will lead our party back to the White House, and we will lead our country back to safety, prosperity, and peace. We will be a country of generosity and warmth. But we will also be a country of law and order. Our Convention occurs at a moment of crisis for our nation. The attacks on our police, and the terrorism in our cities, threaten our very way of life. Any politician who does not grasp this danger is not fit to lead our country. Americans watching this address tonight have seen the recent images of violence in our streets and the chaos in our communities. Many have witnessed this violence personally, some have even been its victims. I have a message for all of you: the crime and violence that today afflicts our nation will soon come to an end. Beginning on January 20th 2017, safety will be restored. The most basic duty of government is to defend the lives of its own citizens. Any government that fails to do so is a government unworthy to lead. It is finally time for a straightforward assessment of the state of our nation. I will present the facts plainly and honestly. We cannot afford to be so politically correct anymore. So if you want to hear the corporate spin, the carefully-crafted lies, and the media myths the Democrats are holding their convention next week. But here, at our convention, there will be no lies. We will honor the American people with the truth, and nothing else.

Portal is one of my favorite puzzle games to date. Portal's unique and innovative gameplay makes it a very enjoyable game. Many of Portal's levels are difficult (especially the bonus levels), but there is immense satisfaction after competing challenging levels. Aside from the gameplay, Portal also includes a complex and mysterious story with ties to Valve's Half Life universe. Portal's atmosphere in-game does a great job at making the user feel as if the user is alone and deserted from any human activity. Portal's story and exceptional gameplay combine to make a remarkable video game. Portal does feature a short campaign, but it is made up redeeming qualities like the well written story and original gameplay. Portal is a great video game that is definitely worth a purchase.

A humorous first person puzzle game pitting you against an evil overlord computer system with your only 'weapon' being a Portal Gun that lets you open 2 color-coded portals on certain walls & floors. A great twist on Valve's penchant for box & physics puzzles with an engaging story that will pull you through the (relatively short) campaign. If you crave more after the campaign you can download or create your own custom maps using the same tools as any other source game. An easy to pickup and play must-play for anyone.

The last time I played this game was probably multiple years ago, but I felt that it deserved this review. Portal was my very first Steam game; in fact, it was the game that inspired me to get steam. My friend showed it to me at his house, and I absolutely loved it. Before I left, I looked at the screen and saw that the application used to run the game was called Steam. I went home, got steam, and got Portal. This game is awesome, from its puzzles to its story to its characters. It may not have a ton of replay value, but it is still a worthwhile purchase that people will love. I love this game, and Portal 2. If you are on the fence about Portal, buy it. You won't regret it, and if you do, there's always refunds.

Portal is a straight-foward masterpiece. Back when Valve used to actually MAKE any games, amazing ♥♥♥♥ like this was released. Portal is a strategic puzzle game, with of course portals.   The game starts you out with waking up from a futuristic bed, (trying not to spoil much here). A robotic-woman voice announces that you are going to go through a series of tests and that the main goal here is to have fun, although some major injuries may occur. Later in the game you encounter the portal gun. With this, you can   shoot and create you're own portals.   You must use these Portals to solve many puzzles you encounter. You will also have to use Weighted Companion cubes to help you access closed doors.   Now moving on the the Graphics and Performance. The graphics to this day are still AMAZING. Valve does a great job on making a plain game look so GOOD. As for performance, i NEVER lost my 60 fps, so the performance is PERFECT. With my PC specs, this game was able to run at the highest settings without a single problem! The performance and graphics on Portal are Spot-on PERFECT! :D   The game itself is amazing, but only one thing threw me off:   THE MAIN GAME IS ONLY AROUND 2-3 HOURS LONG.   The game itself is VERY short, which may ruin the whole experience for a lot of players.  But luckily, the game expands SO much more once you have completed the main game itself, unlocks the main 13-16 chambers of the main game, and adds mini challenges to the 6 chambers, known has the   Challenge Chambers.

My recommendation of NO to Portal is based on an analysis of 'is this worth it'. It's not a 'bad' game, it just isn't an investement. It's a throw-away.  As far as the game is concerned there's nothing really fundamentally flawed about it. It's not broken in any technical sense. It does provide entertainment. It does looks nice. So on and so on.  Unfortunately, I completed it in one sitting of ~82 minutes, playing casually. So yes it's short. But short games can still be great. This however isn't one of those because, there is no replay value (short of hunting a grand total of 15 achievements). Really there's only one way to finish a level; so once the puzzle is solved, it's solved. There aren't really any easter eggs, no multiplayer, no alternate endings, nothing to make me want to come back to it.  Even among all the positive reviews for Portal, the average game time is much LESS than 10 hours.  My recommendation: find a friend who has it, play it and be done with it. Alternatively, Steam has so many sales on many other games that provide much better bang for buck in terms of value, all the time. You won't miss much having this curious but forgettable item in your library.  ---EDIT--- I would like to state that at the time I wrote this, the full price was USD$20, which was the point of my review. It's a game everyone should experience, but it wasn't worth the full price considering the amount of, or lack of content that the average player would experience (which you can see from all the other reviews is only a few hours with the exception of some who managed almost 30).  The game is now 10$ which is better, but even then I would wait for a sale. It's not a reflection of the games technical quality, but rather the value of entertainment to cost when compared to other games availabe which provide much better ratio.  Either way, thanks for reading! ---/EDIT---

Last Played: May 2014 PROS: + GLADOS is actually really funny + Looks good, even after 6 years CONS: - Really short and really easy - Neither revolutionary nor evolutionary REVIEW: If we are being honest, Portal is not a puzzle game, despite many claims to the contrary. It is a 'puzzle-ish' game for people who like shooters. I liked that it was difficult to die, since it made it easier to focus on finding solutions to the 'puzzles', but even with easy deaths the hard part about this game isn't figuring out what to do, it is doing it with somewhat fiddly controls (played using an XBOX 360 controller). Still, if the game disappoints on puzzle satisfaction, it really delivers on dry humor. Your handler, GLADOS is very funny and when she sings the credits song you can't help but grin. The graphics are still shiny (some texture mapping looks bad, but doesn't detract too badly) even after 6 years, which is no small feat as games start to age. As others have said, the level of difficulty will probably see you finishing the base game in less than 3 hours, even if you get stuck-a disadvantage since it significantly boosts your $ cost per hour of entertainment. This also hurts a decision to buy because Portal introduced no really new elements to physics puzzlers nor did it do them especially better, it seems to owe its current popularity to previously high reviews (much like Angry Birds).  Still, one of the best measures of a game is whether you'll remember it after you're done, and I have to say I will remember Portal. Just don't spend more than $5 on it.

Excellent game!  Simple controls parred with an intriguing store line make you dissapointed by the length of the overall experience. Rounding out at roughly 2 1/2 hours total, this game is an amazing journey. Mechanics is the word that comes to mind when reviewing this game.  Visuals:  Simple surroundings (square rooms, bland halways, same elevator....) won't turn any heads or break any rules....that is until you start walking through walls...again and again. Portal animations are done well including being able to watch yourself run through the portal you're running through. The character model animations are a little stiff, but since there isn't any 3rd person option this doesn't really play a major role. Trust me when I say that you'll be to busy making yourself dizzy running through portals to worry about watching yourself...run through portals.  Gameplay:  Simple until you get to the more reactionary parts of the later game. Dying isn't a punishment as you start back at the begining of the smaller puzzles while the larger ones have checkpoints (sometimes multiple) so you don't have to waste time from the start. This game focuses on simple mechanics (4 or 5 i think) and then extrapilates them (in different combinations) into a 2 1/2 hour experience. This more often than not has been done poorly by previous games but when parred with a comical (homicidal) mainframe, it makes for an enjoyable romp.  Sound:  Foot steps sound normal as does the landing sound after jumping or falling. No death sound is used (you won't miss it...) though one was used for the multiple security drones you encounter (and will inevitably oust.) The star in this game (concerning sound) is by far the mainframe computer out to kill you for her experiments. Her dry (logical) take on your circumstances (and your hopeful demise) is ALWAYS well timed to break up any transition as well as giving the player a well timed laugh. I found myself playing the game again just to hear what she had to say...again....  Overall:  I love this game. It's something that my children have attempted to play and enjoy (though the later levels are beyond their skill level) and one I've loved playing again and again. I can't wait to play it again if for no other reason than to listen to the credits again.     The cake is a lie.      .....or is it?

Portal is a first person puzzle oriented game developed by Valve Corporation. The game version which is available in Steam was release on 10th October 2007 as a content of Orange Box. There are many other versions of this game. This game concept came from the game 'Narbacular Drop'. When valve designed the game there are many developer from Narbacular Drop developer team. The latest release of this game was an Android port for the NVidia Shield which was released on 12th May 2014. A sequel, Portal 2, was released in 2011.   This game is designed with several sets of puzzles which are distributed into 19 Test Chambers. The player character Chell have to solve the puzzles using teleporting. At the starting point of every test chamber there is a projector for briefing. Chell have to grab “the Aperture Science Handheld Portal Device” also known as portal gun. By using that gun Chell can make two kinds of portals one is blue portal other is orange portal. From game play we come to know that Chell is solving these puzzles as the Aperture Science Enrichment Center promised to give her a cake at the end of all 19 tests. Throughout the game the artificial intelligence GLaDOS (Genetic Lifeform and Disk Operating System) will monitor Chell. At the end of last test chamber we come to know that the promise of cake is fake. The main objective of the game is to solve 19 puzzles & rescue herself form that fake promise. At the end of the game if you can destroy GLaDOS you can get that promised cake. Though from the game play we came to know 'The cake is lie'. But as per my point of view it's not a lie.   This science fiction game is not as long as valve’s other games, it takes hardly 2-3 hours to complete the 19 puzzles, though till date over four million copies of the game have been sold. The player character Chell is portrayed by Alésia Glidewell & voiced by Mary Kae Lrvin. GLaDOS is voiced by Ellen McLain in English-language version and finally the end credits song “Still Alive” written by Jonathan Coulton also sang by Ellen McLain.  Though it’s a short game but still I’ll recommend to purchase & play. I’m sure after playing you will realize why this game is so popular till date. Now I'm waiting for Portal 2

I know there's a lot of hype over this game, but it 100% lives up to it. Controls are consistently good. Visuals hold up well and contribute a lot to the atmosphere, as does the music. (Mariachi opening music is the BEST.) Characterization and story is very well done, unexpected for a puzzle-based FPS.  The difficulty is fair; while not overly difficult, it requires you to use a lot of mental acuity and quick reflexes at the same time. There's only a few hours of gameplay, but there's no filler; a great example of a game that's short but sweet. The main hook in Portal, the gameplay, is one of the most innovative things ever done in an first-person game. It's about 8 years old at this point, but instead of becoming outdated, I think it's just become more apparent that this game is a classic. Definite recommendation.

I like this game because it's unique. It's not a first person shooter like it initially appears to be, it's a first person puzzle game. Don't let the word 'puzzle' fool you into getting the idea that this is a typical puzzle game though, it's very action packed. The entire game revolves around the concept that there are blue portals, and orange portals, and that objects and people who pass through one portal appear out the other. You use the portals to navigate the stages, alter the paths of moving objects, and to use momentum to 'fling' yourself around the stages. The game is very short, so you could easily play through it in a single run. Those who want more can play the advanced chambers, which are remastered versions of story chambers that have been modified to be more challenging. If that isn't enough, the game has a surprisingly deep story. I recommend this to anyone who wants a quick fix, or a little change from the 'shoot 'em up' norm that video games have come to.

Easily one of the most enjoyable games I've ever played. What at first seems to be a clever and unique puzzler, becomes something much more engrossing and intelligent. In addition to some fantastic puzzles, and a really interesting core game mechanic (the portal of the namesake, which often lend themselves to some mind-bending and hilarious moments), Portal excels at minimalist storytelling, and has a perfectly wicked and dark sense of humor. My first playthrough six years ago still ranks as one of my favorite all time gaming experiences, and subsequent playthroughs are a must, all in spite of some serious linearity, limited alternative solutions, and a very short run time.  Easily a must-play for gamers and non-gamers alike!

Released within the Orange Box in 2007, Portal was quite unexpected, at least compared to Team Fortress 2 and Half Life 2 : Episode 2, which were the stars of the Orange Box at that time. With its short single-player campaign, and its stripped down graphics (close in term of quality to Half Life 2, released years prior), Portal was to be considered as a bonus in the Orange Box, or even some kind of draft.  Yet, Portal managed to stir up the curiosity and the interest of the gaming community. First, the story line is as simple as it is mysterious. Portal is set in the Half Life universe, seemingly at the same time as the first Half Life. The main character is Chell, a young and mute Gordon Freeman-like woman, who wakes up in a huge complex, belonging to Aperture Science, the main competitor of Black Mesa. Chell will be guided by GLaDOS, a strange AI, through a series of 'tests', in order to attend some kind of 'party'.  What first looks like a training level slowly evolves toward a mix of FPS and puzzle game, as the player will have to use the portal gun to solve the 'tests', which consists in 3D physics enigmas. Create a blue and an orange portal, and what goes through one portal comes out of the other with the same momentum. You then will have to use the law of physics to solve the puzzles. This original concept provides a very interesting and intelligent challenge. It's just a shame that Portal was developped as a mini-game, so it's neither long nor difficult.  But aside form this originality, the atmosphere of Portal is quite intriguing. Nothing is explained regarding to why Chell is here, or to who she is (hence the simplicity of the sotry !). And as she travels through this disturbingly empty complex, she is permanently lectured by GLaDOS. The AI was seeminlgy conceived as a twisted version of HAL 9000, with its quiet voice, but dangerous schemes and worrying speech elements. And let's not forget the famous and popular closing song, 'Still Alive', sung by GLaDOS.  All of this allow for a unique experience, that I recommend you to try, at least for a few hours (you won't need much more to complete the campaign).

Ingredients: 1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter 2. 1/2 cup white sugar 3. 1/2 cup brown sugar 4. 1/4 cup water 5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon 6. 1 pinch salt 7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced 8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie   Directions: 1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C). 2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside. 3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices. 4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal. 5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust. crust and crimp to seal. 6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

I feel that three things must be stressed for those like myself who arrived late to the party:  1) Portal is a classic, and absolutely worth playing if you haven't done so yet. Even if puzzle games are not generally your cup of tea, this game takes a unique approach to the genre, exploiting many different creative facets of its relatively simple gameplay mechanics. But the highlight of this game, as I see it, is its extremely witty and often downright hilarious dialogue (or perhaps monologue would be a more appropriate word).  2) That said, if you are still uncertain about whether or not you will enjoy this game, I feel compelled to recommend that you wait until its on sale to make the purchase. My reason for this is that the full campaign is disappointingly short (my friend and I both beat the entire game in 3.5 hours)... about 2 hours into the game, the plot takes a twist of sorts, and suddenly gains significant momentum that almost gives the impression that the main crux of the game is finally starting. But no such luck... about an hour later, you realize you've beaten the game, which feels like it ends right after it truly begins.   3) Replay value is low in my opinion. Recently I let my friend play through it on my computer while I watched, and I found that I remembered practically every solution right away. However, even merely sitting in the passenger seat as my friend traversed the angular corridors of Aperture Science Laboratories, I found myself thoroughly entertained by the clever writing... and, of course, my friend's confused frustration in all the same sections of the game that I struggled with.  Conclusion: Even if this isn't the type of game you would normally be interested in, I think most will quickly discover why this game has received such acclaim throughout the years. I think most gamers should not hesitate to add this game to their library... assuming the price is right ($9.99 for an old game that is *so* short might be hard to justify for some, but if you happen to find it on sale, waste no time in picking it up).

I didn't like Portal. I'm sorry. I know most people do -- and you probably will -- but I'm just not a huge fan of it. The environment of Aperature Science and GLaDOS is phenomenal. The story, or whatever the overarching concept should be called, it cool too. But I didn't like the game.  I picked it up for free when I first got a steam account as part of a special offer. I know, I know -- if it's free, I shouldn't be complaining about it, but I just don't understand what all the hype is about. There are plenty of more dynamic puzzlers out there, and the test chambers are boring and repetitive for the first 75% of the game. The challenges have standards that are set ridiculously high (it took me literally the entire time I've had a Steam account to beat it), and that makes achievement hunting on Portal a very frustrating experience.   The largest detractor for me, however, is the face people make when I say I don't like Portal. There appears to be some law in the gaming world that I /must/ love this game. I played it, I beat it. I even finally got all the achievements, but I still feel the same way. I understand why others may like it, but I don't. The only mystery left is why I can't seem to have my own individual preferences.   The cultural enshrinement of Portal is well-deserved. Like I said, I understand why people would like this game. It just never really appealed to me, however, and after the first playthrough, I was quite ready to be done with it. I can only hope that the stigma attached to my dislike of this game isn't a burden shared by others (the measley few percent) that also gave Portal a negative review. It's actually quite a hassle.  I didn't like this game. I want to not recommend it. But I will anyway, because I know you will.

I still find it hard to believe there are people out there, alarmingly many, gamers mind you, I've spoken to who have yet to play Portal. A game where you bend spacetime! Well, just space, actually. But nonetheless... Make a doorway to go almost anywhere you want in these lab environments and use it to solve puzzles. If you like brain teasers, then once you get through the intro levels, this is the game for you. And the implications of frequently flying through the air this, that, and every which way lend Portal a childlike giddy fun quality that you rarely find. Garry's mod also has this, but it's more of a small sandbox with a ton of tools, whereas this game has structure and narrative. If you enjoy mystery in a narrative, then you will arguably enjoy Portal as well. It has no story in the traditional sense, but little bits and pieces that you put together to get a greater picture. I know many of you know Portal already, but those who don't are really missing out. Addiction is 86.557 % guaranteed.

Great game. The initial rooms are dead easy, and in the later rooms it's easy to die. Learning to 'think with Portals' is tricky and the puzzles do keep stretching your problem solving skills, and of course, the dry humour keeps you from getting *too* frustrated.  My biggest bugbear with Portal is that one of the main mechanics gives me wicked motion sickness - as you jump through one portal, you're spat out from the other at the same speed, which can have an interesting effect on the camera! Not everyone will have this problem but I do recommend taking a break frequently, particularly if rollercoasters are NOT your thing.  That said, Portal is a little gem that will keep you entertained.

Portal — although approaching 10 years of age — is still very innovative and different game. If you haven't played it, I would whole heartedly recommend it.  The puzzle mechanic of the game, portals, is surprisingly complex. It takes some time to wrap your head around it, but you'll be solving complex puzzles in no time. The learning curve is very smooth, to the point that you don't realise that every test chamber is a tutorial that introduces some mechanic or interaction.  The best thing about this game is how open it is despite looking very clean and linear. Most test chambers (Yes, including the first push button one) have some secrets or alternative way to complete it.  The only complaint about this game is that it's short, which is why I would also recommend Portal's sequel, Portal 2.

I think I prefer Portal to the sequel. This seems to break videogame laws since ( as oppossed to films as famously stated in Scream 2) video games generally get better with age, kind of like Monica Belluci. All you have to do is update the graphics a bit, add more enemies, fix a fre flaws in the original and voila? A better game, right?  Well I don't know if it's always that simple, sure for a game that depends on graphics, guns and enemies (not being elitist here I love those games) you can just add more but when games rely on a concept or emotion primarily to work they don't necessarily get better with iteration.  One example of this would be the Final Fantasy series, since the core of an RPG relates to your investment in the world and characters and can be established just as well with sprites and SNES's as with super impressive visuals its perhaps not surprising this series hasn't neccessarily got better at a linear rate. When the world exploration has to be sacrificied for high fidelity visuals it lends to a very unsatisfying 'sugar high' type experience.  I guess the other point relates to the fact that sometimes the thing we love about the game isn't what we think. For example after playing Tomb Raider many people wanted more action but Tomb Raider 2 (although still awesome, I mean you could fight yeti's with an M16 in that game, come on) actually seemed to sacrifice some of the enjoyment of exploration when it throw more bad guys at you.  Portal is more in the third category kind of like the films of M Night Shamalayn, the game arguably was so memorable because it was so different, so when you add in a sequel (however well designed) the game simply can't recapture that 'wow' factor of the original.

WARNING: THIS GAME MAY BE ADDICTING AND LEAVE YOU WANTING MORE  The Portal series of games have a very simple concept. You must make your way thru a testing facility ripe with obstacles and armed only with a gun that shoots 2 different colored portals into surfaces (walls, floors, ceilings, panels, etc.). You enter one of the portals and come out the other while being prompted along by a sarcastically condescending and evil (?) female voiced AI. Simple right? Mwahaha ... think and think again :)  The game was artfully made. The ambience of the testing facility is nothing less than captivating. Each test chamber is a game in and of itself. With each completed test chamber you'll get a 'pat yourself on the back' sense of achievement.   Try it - You'll like it.

I finished Portal 2 before I played the first installment so this didn't have quite the impact on me that the second one did. It shares many of the same characteristics as the second (wonderfully rendered, detailed environments, innovative physics and game play, challenging levels, etc) but for me, the game was too short. I finished it in about a little over half of the time it took me to finsh the second one (and I don't like to speed through games; I like to take them in and enjoy the details that the developers put into them. I have a background in 2D/3D graphcs so I know something about what goes into these environments).  Also lacking (sadly) was the humor I found so enjoyable in the second game. There also wasn't much in the way of a story to explain why you were there; I kept waiting for the story to develop to fill in these blanks but it never really materialized.  That said, it was still a great game and I thoroughly enjoyed it. I suggest Portal 1 first; this will give you a greater appreciation for how much work these folks put into the second one, and it really showed.

Well I can see why everyone likes this game so much.   PLOT:  There ain't much of a plot, get Portal 2 for that, but it basically boils down to 'you're stuck in some labs, there's an AI who lies to you and will stop at nothing to kill you and you have to use your little gun to complete chambers and then escape' written like that, this game sounds rubbish.  GAMEPLAY  If you like a good story, try Portal 2. If you're more focused on puzzles, play both Portal and Portal 2 (and get the Portal Level Pack in LEGO Dimensions, like I did) because in this game you'll be taking on lots of puzzles. There are 19 test chambers, an escape sequence and a finale to play through, and you have to rely on the Portal Gun, a machine that can create gateways, to get from entrance to exit. I came into the game thinking 'Oh I'll just fire a portal by the entrance, fire one at the exit and then be off' but that's when you find out about the gun's one weakness - black walls. You'll also be using plenty of cubes to activate buttons and deflect lasers, and you'll encounter the GODAWFUL TURRETS!  THE TURRETS ARE ONE OF THE MOST ANNOYING THINGS I'VE MET IN ANY GAME! THEIR STUPID HIGH PITCHED VOICES! I EVEN HAD TO GET MY FRIEND TO COMPLETE THE FIRST TURRET CHAMBER!   I just smashed up the turret I got in the LEGO Dimensions Portal pack. That feels much better,  The game has 98% positive reviews, what the hell are you still doing here?
Just buy it. Even if you hate it the credits make everything worth it. I promise.

Portal is a first person puzzle game that works on the concept of, well, portals.  portal has a simple plot. You are a test subject within the science labs deep below the surface, used to test the 'portal gun', a device which, funnily enough, allows you to make hot fudge sunday, well, only in an alternative universe, in this one however, it makes portals. Your goal is to beat each room, learning the mechanics of the game while getting messed around by a psychotic AI.  The gameplay is simple, you have a gun, it shoots a blue and a orange portal, allowing you to travel between them. Using this single mechanic and basic movement, you must solve reach room in turn. Where the game shines is the creativity of both the puzzles and the way it forces you to think outside the box, while inside a box. Each puzzle feels satisfying to beat and your reward for beating them, another puzzle, even better than the last. Later on the game gets more fast paced and forces you to use all that you've learned, and apply them offensively.  Where portal truly shines however is its humor. It starts off rather tame and slowly eases you into a range of odd ball humor, normally centred around insulting you, or just being mean in general. I rarely comes off as completely mean spirited however, and from my experience, rather light hearted and teasing whenever its aimmed at you, whenever its on a different topic its creative. The big star of the game, glados, is the source of all this banter, everything she says is golden, even if she is the main antagonist, she's lovable in the way only an entertaining bad guy can be.  Portal also features a rather simple visual style, which is deliberate if you consider that the entire thing is based in a testing facility. This not only helps remove any enviromental confusion when solving puzzles, only allowing you to focus on the raw elements of each one, but really does help hammer home a feeling of isolation, not only due to a lack of other people, but a lack of sensory stimulation. There is an interesting aspect of psychology at play here and studies documenting the effects of sensory deprivation, something which this game does apply rather well to an extent. The game does have music, and when you focus on it the music is rather delightful, it has a very clean, syth style that does not use any traditional instrument. But its very easy to forget that it is even there at times.  Overall, portal is a classic which deserves its place in gaming history, its a fantastic puzzle game and is nothing short of satisfying from start to finish. I would recommend this to anyone, as its perfect for people new to gaming, vets of the entire medium and will be able to keep the attention of just about anyone, regardless of taste.

I'm not someone who normally writes reviews and I definitely don't typically write outrageous and universally sweeping statements on the internet as there is enough of that already. That goes out the window for this game, which I played on a different account (hence the low play time). Here is the one and only possible legitimate criticism of Portal:  'I don't like puzzle games.'  I will follow this up with more ridiculous statements. This game is the best game ever made. It is a master-class in blending design and humor, technical work and art. It came out of nowhere and did not overstay its welcome. I will follow this up with more outrageous statements. If you think Portal is an objectively bad game, you don't understand games. Or maybe you are immature, an idiot, high, drunk or all of these things. Either way your taste in games, at the very least, is terminaly skewed, and you must flock to someone of a more discerning palate for guidance in the rest of your life. For the rest of you, if you never play another game, spend the 5 cents and play this game. You will not regret it. And if you do you have bigger issues to spend time regretting.

Rating: 7/10  Not exactly worth the current £6.99, however it is a remarkably good game. The graphics aren't too bad, and the gameplay is very interesting (even if it is rather short). The puzzles are extremely fun to solve, as long as they're not too complex. Since you'll finish the game in a few hours, you don't have time to gain experience with the game mechanics and the game will progress too fast; eventually, you'll find that the difficulty has been raised very high and that your current knowledge is not enough to solve the puzzle without getting annoyed. However, the whole concept of 'portals' makes this game extremely interesting and it's definitely worth playing, even if it is quite short.
A unique FPS experience. The fantastic humour and extremely fun (and cerebral) gameplay help reinvigorate the somewhat stagnant FPS genre. Highly recommended.

Portal is a short first person 3D puzzle game that was designed to be in the Orange Box, along with Half Life 2, Half Life 2 Episodes One and Two, and Team Fortress 2. In the game, you play as Chell, a silent protagonist who navigates her way through Apeture Laboratories, a testing faucility for the Aperture Science Handheld Portal Device (ASHPD), or Portal Gun.   The Portal Gun shoots two portals: an orange and blue one. If you go through one, you come out the other. You use these portals to solve puzzles, or test chambers. You are commentated on by GLADoS, a seemingly friendly A.I. You are promised cake and grief counseling at the end of the chambers by GLADoS, but as you make your way through the lonely test chambers, you start to suspect that not only is there something wrong with GLADoS, but with Aperture Laboratories itself.   The game itself is brilliant, with difficult puzzles and intriguing plot, this game is all around wonderfull. My only complaint is that the game is too short. On your first playthrough, it will take you 2 hours max to complete the game. And that's being too generous. I understand that they had to make it short because the main game in the Orange Box was Half Life 2, but they could have added more puzzles.    Another interesting feature of the game if you're into video game backstory is the fact that this game fits into the Half Life universe. So if you like finding all the cute little easter eggs that connect the games together, go for it. However, Portal 2 has more crossovers to Half Life.    This is one of my favorite games of all time, and I will give this game a 9/10 for the shortness. If you haven't played Portal, fork out the extra ten dollars, enjoy this exellent game, and remember that the cake is a lie.

Since becoming a PC Gamer pretty much full time this year after getting my new gaming PC I've made a habit out of actually finishing games. Many of the games I'm finishing are such classic games as Portal. I actually bought Portal as part of a Steam sale a few years ago when it was one of the games on Steam that actually played on the Mac. So Portal has been around since 2007 and now 7 years later I played through it and what a great experience it was. As somone who mostly reaches for a players guide especially in games like this I actually played through the 19 levels of Portal only having to check a guide twice (mostly on level 19 and one of the two times I was actually doing what I needed to do just not clicking in the right place). My enjoyment and overall feel of accomplishment actually figuring out the levels on my own was very fullfilling. Portal is not a long game, for me I spent about 5 hours total, there are bonus maps but I've not played them at this time. So I guess this isn't really a review but rather an overview of my enjoyment of the game, a game that is probably at this point just more of an intro to actually moving on to Portal 2, which of course I plan to do now. At $10 Portal has enough content but it's often on sales for $5 or less or in a bundle, if you don't own it and are thinking about it, just stop thinking and pick it up. You owe it to yourself and your gaming collection.

Personal Rating: 8.8/10  This game is another innovative masterpiece by Valve, only this time with a different twist. Instead of being able to lift and launch items with the Gravity Gun, you get a neat, a possibly more useful, device known as the Aperture Science Handheld Quantum Tunneling Device, mostly referred to as a Portal Gun. Wow, Valve must like futuristic guns... Anyway, this device can fire a blue portal (left-click) and a red/orange portal (right-click). These portals are spacially linked, so, in simple terms, place something in one portal and it'll exit out of the other. Throughout the game, you are guided through various chambers, which require the use of the Portal Gun, by an automated feminine voice, which belongs to the CPU of the entire facility, known as Genetic Lifeform and Disk Operating System, or GLaDOS for short. The voice seems to desire to help you, promising you a portion of cake in the end, but can you really trust this machine? With great gameplay, intriguing mechanics, an epic final battle, and an extremely popular credits theme, this game is downright amazing, and I recommend it to any puzzle fanatics or gamers in general. The game only has one flaw: It is rather easy.
