If you haven't played this game then where have you been? This game has one of the best stories out there. You wake up in a cell, with a toilet, a mug and a strange blue portal on the wall. As you venture through the game you find the blue section of the portal gun, which allows to place the blue portal on walls. As you venture further, you come across the orange section of the portal gun. Now you have the ability to place both blue and orange portals. You use these portals to solve puzzling test chambers,    and eventually fight your way to the boss at the end of the game.    Overall, this game is one of the best experiences out there, and you will be kept busy with the quite challenging puzzles as you progress further into the game.  4.5/5

I bought this game while it was on sale in a pack with the second game. I found it really enjoyable to return to a game I'd previously played on lend from a friend, but hadn't beaten.  Although the game is rather short, it leaves you mentally invigorated to solve the puzzles and make your way through the seeminly empty test facility. Acommpanied by the disembodied voice of GLaDOS, a snarky AI whom puts little stock into your intelligence, you are aided only by your own problem solving skills and a portable wormhole generator. You better learn how to think with portals, or you're going to have a tough time. The graphics are clean and rather beautiful for the time at which this game was released and the soundtrack is great for adding even more tension to the seemingly hopeless situations that arise in the game. I recommend this game to anyone who is looking to play a great game that has been well-loved since release or for something that truly tests your patience and perception of surroundings.

For any of you who do not know what Portal is about, you're in for a treat. Anybody who enjoys mixing science and puzzles will definitely enjoy this gravity-law-breaking, quirky-joke-making, and highly-addictive First Person Shooter game. As you wake up in a glass case inside Aperature Laboratories, you take the roll of a female test subject who must escape the laboratory only using portals created by the Portal Gun. As you acquire BOTH parts of the Portal Gun, the puzzles get creative as you find your way to the elevator at the end of each level. Manipulate portals to avoid being detected by Aperature Machine Gun Turrets, use Companion Cubes to open doors, and remember the speed law of portals: 'As in laymans terms, speedy thing goes in, speedy things goes out.'

PCGamer magazine called Portal 'the number one game of all time'. I have to agree with them. There is simply no other game with as unique a concept or great a challenge. Although lacking graphical polish, Portal still is in a class by itself with its unique gameplay and mind-bending puzzles. Coupled with Gameinformer magazines' number one character of the decade (Glados) and probably the most difficult achievement ever (Aperture Science), Portal is enough to make puzzle lovers drool, but really anyone who tires of shooting things up will enjoy this game--a must play for any hardcore gamer!
Do you like puzzles? Do you like being confused? Do you like being condescended to? Do you like developing warm fuzzy feelings for inanimate objects? Well then this game is for you :D

Ya first start out and have the mechanics explained to you and it's like 'Oh cool!'.   Then you slowly work through all the neat puzzles that all introduce a new element into the mix to keep things challenging, and your proud of yourself for finally conquering the game.   'Congratulations, you're thinking with portals!'  NO. Your not.  Your not thinking with portals until you attempt the challenges it throws at you, (speed, portals used, and steps taken)   No other gaming experience I've hard is close to the hectic experience of flying from portal to portal, shooting through space, totally disoriented and praying that you don't mess up a shot.   Check youtube for videos of such insanity.

First person view puzzle game where you essentially navigate series of 3D rooms using Portal Gun as your primary tool that lets you set up a pair of eponymous portals connecting two surfaces. Preservation of momentum included when entering one portal and exiting the other. Your goal is to creatively use those portals to get yourself out of test chambers.  The puzzling thinking-with-portals experience is greatly enhanced with a humorous (and progressively darker) engrossing ongoing story set in Half-Life universe, that puts you in shoes of a silent protagonist Chell, a test subject of Aperture Science's (perma 2nd place rival of Black Mesa) now-famous AI, GLaDOS.  The game taken everyone by surprise with its perfect polish. It's an inspiring success story of student university project, Narbacular Drop (available free), taken under wings of a successful game studio.  Portal may be considered bit short, the main story is finished in a matter of hours, pretty much in one setting, as you won't stop until it's done, and hearing the 'I'm still alive' (end credits song) is really a cathartic experience (that also makes you wonder.. really? she's alive? ok, possibly sequel incoming - true enough obviously nowadays).  But the shortness mostly means there's no extra filler fluff, however there are additional challenges awaiting those who want more after finishing the story - a few tougher versions of some chambers and time trials / minimum portals trials and some nicely designed achievements to keep you busy longer.

A masterfully presented adventure that's short but sweet - but very intelligent in its level design. I won't spoil much (but then again everyone knows this game) but the first half of the game is really just preparation for the later levels, where you have to escape Aperture Science and take down its hostile A.I., GLaDOS. The game starts out with simple puzzles, introducing concepts which get used later on in more difficult puzzles, such as flinging, and teaches you to associate certain objects with other objects. You only get one item throughout the game - the Portal Gun, which is upgraded very early on - and there's no time limit to complete the chambers. Even the final boss, which is timed, gives you more than enough time. Add a dark sense of humour and a well-written, minimalist cast on top, and you have a masterpiece.

For a long time now I have been looking for a game which breaks new ground and does something different. This is that game and I loved it. At first glance it looks like a first person shooter. But instead of shooting at baddies, your weapons create two ends of a portal, through which you can then make progress. So the puzzle is to make your way through the labyrinth of the game by solving the spatial problems put before you. You get to jump onto moving platforms, and pick up and deposit objects to help you. There are also things that shoot at you.  But what makes the game particularly interesting is the bizarre computer HAL type overseer that accompanies you through the game, promising cake at one moment, then threatening to kill you the next. This is very well thought through and very amusing , a real masterstroke. The only real downside is that the game is disappointingly short.  Thoroughly recommended. If you are looking for something different, but well made and enjoyable - get this game.

Portal is a puzzle based game developed by Valve. You are a test subject and thus must solve a series of tests by the will of the resident AI, GLaDOS.  Portal is quite fun, but the main game is rather short. The puzzles, though very fun, are rather easy once you understand the game mechanics. However, there are many hours outside the main story manifested in challenges and advanced chambers. The story is rather shallow, consisting only of the interaction between you and GLaDOs. However the script writer really needs a metal the script IS rather humorous. Combat is almost non-existant, the closest thing being the puzzles involving turrets (who are rather likeable), and they are quite easy to dispatch as long as you get behind them.    Would I recommend this? Yes. This is an incredibly good game. BUT. It's overshadowed by it's successor, Portal 2. Actually, I'd advise getting the Portal Bundle next time there's a sale, they both are worth your money, but you'll get more bang out of your buck from Portal 2.

People say this game is too short. But, as I see it, quality over quantity. It has amazing writing and the graphics are very good (for a game from 2007).  The comedy never stops. Whilst being for slightly more attentive players (the third time playing through I finally got all the jokes) and the story nice and simple. As you go through, you start to see more of how GLaDOS acts, and get hints of what is happening on the outside.  The concept is simple: you are trapped in Aperture Science Laboratories, and an AI named GLaDOS is basically forcing to do puzzles the promise of a certain confectionary at the end. You can fire a 'Aperture Science Handheld Portal Device' to create portals to reach the exit of all puzzles, which get progressively harder.  The game is set in the same universe as Half Life. We can see this from multiple things, such as a chart in a side room displaying such things as the profits of Black Mesa and Aperture, and GLaDOS references to the dangers outside at one or two points.  So, all in all, this game is brilliant. 19/10. I'm GLaD I bought this game, OSo GLaD. REMINDER: The Enrichment Center reminds you that the Review will never threaten to stab you and, in fact, cannot speak. In the event that the Review does speak, the Enrichment Center urges you to disregard its advice.  REMINDER PS: Speedy thing goes in, speedy thing goes out. Remember that. It's important.

Portal is, quite simply, one of the greatest puzzle games out there. Its idea is totally original and is for sure a lot of fun. The puzzles can be a bit frustrating at times but are still a joy to play through. Plus, nothing beats the feeling you get after you finally beat the level you spent a long time on. However, the game is more like an experiment. With that in mind, the game is definitely on the shorter side; you'll spend no longer than 4-5 hours on the main campaign. There are also a few challenging bonus levels that really test your skill after you watch the game's credits. Overall, it's a very good experience that is worth the ten dollars. Buy it, especially if it goes on sale. If you're craving more after you've finished this, then pick up the even more superior Portal 2.

Portal's problem is it's length, so pick the game up when an offer comes around.  If you do it's a wonderful puzzle game, fresh, new and rewarding. The game only took me 2.5 hours to beat and while there're advanced maps to play after, it's really only modified version of maps you've already played. The games build by Valve using the Source engine so it runs without a hitch and you'll find all the options you could want in the menus. The goal of the game is to maniplulate portals using a 'portal gun' to solve puzzles and find your way to the exit. The base games are not overly challenging and I didn't find myself getting stuck for longer than a few minutes before I'd figured it out, but you get a nice sense of reward when finishing a stage non the less.  I would recommend this at a sales price simply because it's such a short game.

The number of mysterys and puzzles in the world are vast. What better way to spend your time than by solving these puzzles through reasoning and skill, but most importantly: portals. As its name suggests, portals are a major element of this game. Experience original and fantastic puzzles for yourself in this widely popular franchise. It will not dissapoint.

Portal was a blast. I saw people play this game before, and I always assumed by the looks of it to be a hard puzzle game only meant for the dedicated. I finally picked up Portal for myself, and was confused immediately. How do I get over there if I'm here? Luckily that didn't last. I was surprised how simple the concept was for the portals.   I'm glad that the challenge of this game for me was to figure out how to get to the finish and not how to figure out what portals are. This game was fun difficult, a.k.a. I did not get frustrated with this game. I enjoyed figuring out how to get to where I wanted to go.   GLaDOS was the star of the show. I've never loved a homicidal AI more than her.   Not much of a storyline, but a story isn't need for such a fun puzzle game. You endure the trials and get your revenge and freedom.   Why haven't you bought this game yet?  Also, there are no jump scares.

The progress of this puzzle game is fabulous. I finished it at ease without any need of a walkthrough. It is a short game though, so do yourself a favour and get the second edition too. My only issue is that the voiceover is sometimes quite annoying. While I do understand it's the key element to keep the game moving, I just want to tell it to shut up when I die over at the same spot and hear the same voiceover again.

If you love puzzle games, humour, witty-remarks, and a sassy robot, you'll love Portal.  If you've only played the 2nd Portal, but not the first, you should still buy it. It's honestly really worth checking out, and is very fun.

Portal!! After the game's got so much critical acclaim, seems like there's not much to add, only to ask myself how didn't I play it sooner.  I would start then with a very short list of the things that DID bother me, First, well, the length of course. Nothing new here. I do believe it simply wasn't meant to be too long in the first place but more like a side content to The Orange Box back in the day, but still. Also, soundtrack was a little disappointing in my opinion. And, before completing the main game, I've seen that there are 'challenges' and 'advanced maps', and imagined that they would add more content to the game, but figured out later that these are merely a revisions of the original maps from the campaign.  So, just let me confess here, that Portal didn't completely live up to my expectations. (~Hiding myself from possibly thrown objects~) As this game is so positively accepted I did expect something more. Being so short and the lack of additional content in the base game didn't help much. It was fun but ended too soon, and the story just felt... meeeh. And the challenges started to feel too crazy for me as soon as they started depending on trial&error\some luck, facts which I don't like!  I did grow a lot fonder of Portal as I played through the developers commentary. Hearing their thoughts and the game-making process made me appreciate everything much more, somehow. I even liked better that 'Still Alive' song which at first seemed bizzare and weird to me.  Anyway, I'm not going to fully review this game and describe all of it's good aspects, because you probably know them already, and if not (!?) then you should experience it yourself, even by trying the demo. Just wanted to share my little story of falling in love with the game.  Portal is without a doubt a very extraordinary puzzle game, brilliantly original, and I doubt we'll ever see any other game of the kind. Many other games tried to follow Portal's lead and so far I didn't encounter much success among these attempts.  It goes constantly on sale, and it's actually worth the full price of 10$ as well. If you didn't already, it's time to play!

Portal is a very successful experiment in using the Half-Life 2 Source engine to create a puzzle game in which you use a gun that creates 2 portals that are connected is space. The game does an excellent job in explaining these mechanics, and it's very enjoyable through it's short campaing. There isn't much of a story, but GLaDOS is an iconic figure through the entire game. The game is also generally easy-medium. There's also 6 additional advanced chambers (medium-hard) and 18 challenges (hard-very hard). To complete these, you'll need to learn some tricks. But these are mainly for those who want to master this game, and it's a nice addition. But i easily recommend you to play the story, and in the end you'll want more, which Portal 2 delivers.

Portal is a very short game but was also very prolific when it came out. As part of the Orange Box, Portal was about two hours long but it made you think as you played. Puzzles ranged from simply getting a box from one place to another where others involved tricky jumps to avoid gunfire and crushing pistons. You had no weapons aside from your mind and the ability to place two different colored portals to deal with such challenges. Portal also offers separate challenges to complete if you feel the main game is not enough.  Pick this up with the Orange Box or as a stand alone. Either way, it's usually a bargain.  Just be ready to learn the origin of some of Valve's more well known, albeit slightly ancient memes.

What could be better than a first person shooter turned puzzle game that challenges both your wit and your reflexes? Oh, give it a strong protagonist, an intruiging and sinister villian, and a compelling story. That. What I really enjoy about this game is that it doesn't take the story and smash you over the head with it in wall after wall of painful exposition. Some things are spelled out by GlaDos while others you come across and have to piece together for yourself. The game trusts you to figure out what's going on and I appreciate that. Especially after dying on the same level in the same way eight times in a row. It makes me feel al little better about myself. GlaDos is quite possibly the best video game villian ever written. She's funny and terrifying at the same time, like that one aunt everyone avoids at the family christmas party. They could have easily hammed her up and gone overboard with it but somehow managed to find the perfect balance between cold emotionless android and snarky embittered librarian. The puzzels are challenging, but do-able. There is always a solution even though it is not always obvious. Keep at it and solving the tests becomes almost addicting. Once you get to post game and start the challenges it's even worse. The game is very brief and when you play the second game you discover it only barely scrapes the surface of the Portal world, but I feel like that's fair for a game that was released in a bundle with two other games. It's more like an animated short than a box office movie, but you more than get what you pay for. Seriously, you just need to play it. It is SO GOOD.

Although I beat the game (First Level to credits, not including challenges & etc.) in 2.6 hours (half of which while being half asleep, so I could easily have beaten it in 2), this game is a must have for every Steam account. This game has an interesting puzzle mechanic with the Portals, and constant witty lines coming from the game's narrating bot (and one giant plot twist that the Internet has managed to spoil for just about everyone). The credits song was so touching that I almost wanted to tear up a little. I wish I had auditioned with it in my high school's talent show, but I can't sing, and didn't first play this game until after my graduation. Oh well. If you find the first runthrough a bit easy, you'll love/hate the challenge levels. They are very, very difficult. Oh lawd.  All in all, 10 dollars might be a bit steep (I bought it on sale for 2.49), but this game is most definitely a Valve classic that you have to buy. I am looking forward to playing Portal 2 for the first time shortly.  tl;dr this game is a perfect 10. Buy it. They have cake.

Portal is a spin-off to the Half-Life franchise, except it provides something different to offer. The game takes place entirely in a large advance lab facility called Aperture Labs. Half-Life fans might be familiar with that name as it was mentioned as Black Mesa's competitor in Half-Life 2: Episode 2. Confirming that the game is set in the same universe except focus on a different protagnogist. The main protagnogist is a woman named Chell who is a test subject for Aperture Labs. She awakens in her cell and is greeted by an AI named GlaDOS, who is like a female version of the Hal 9000. GlaDOS monitors Chell throughout the area she is confined in and soon is given instructions to participate in a series of tests in various obstacle courses with only a prototype 'portal gun' as a tool to progress the tests. The portal gun is a highly advance device that shoots out two different rifts of portals: blue and orange. Anything going into the blue portal comes out of the orange portal and vice versa. As Chell goes on her trek of countless obstacles, she eventually discovers that there is something not right about the lab as the windows of the upper floors where the lab staff would normally be present are not there as the spectators and wonders if anyone is stationed at the lab than her. The game offers the same gameplay and layouts as the Half-Life games do except in this game you play as a heroine and the only weapon of choice is a portal gun which you have to use to your advancetage when dealing with various dangers. The puzzles are very well thought up and sometimes appear to be cryptic but there is a solution if you put your mind to it. Portal would go on to being an iconic game in the same level as Counter Strike & Half-Life. Anyone who loves those games will enjoy this game to the core.

Do I even need to explain why Portal is amazing? Portal is a puzzle game, it gives you a concept then gets out. It is an amazing way to test your mind while still being fun. Although this game isn't as story heavy, it did give birth to one of the most GOOD popular games of 2011. I still play this game and beat it when I am feeling bored and I love to come back and to see what gave birth to a legend and what is a legend.   Gameplay: Portal's gameplay is quite simple, to explain at least. You use portals to your advantage, along with buttons that activate a part of the puzzle. Two buttons are in the game, one that you press and one that you need a cube to put on. There are also lift pads is what I will call them, they take you across the map. Also, there are energy balls (xdxdxd) that kill you if you are hit by one. Lastly, there is DEADLY GOO!! Simple, you fall in, you die. Easy. Not so easy.   Story: To be honest not much story is in this Portal game. Well, at the time. Now theories are everywhere because of the second installment. Anyway, the story basically is that you are a test subject that volunteered a long time ago to test some new gadgets the factory was making. Then GLADOS, the AI that you fight against went rouge and killed everyone working there. You, now go through HER tests and then end up -SSPPOOIILLEERRSS-  Conclusion: Buy Portal.

I love this game. It was the first I bought on steam and it is amazing. The closed in feel you get is unique to this game, and I loved every second of it. You get the feeling you anen't just being watched by GLADoS, but also by scientists. The game does have flaws though. The game is a bit short (only 19 test chambers) but does have extra modes (least step, portal and time challenges) and a harder difficulty. But I still love this game. I would give it a 8,5/10

Game that stands out and pulls some emotion strings along the way  The game that came as a part of an Orange box and at the first glance stands out when compared to HL and TF. Before playing the most intruiging- there will be no shooting which is a key factor when it comes to Valve games (CS, HL, TF are FPS with various weaponry etc.).  The setting is for a player to feel like a lab rat with a AI giving orders and giving remarks about your performance. Controls, the aim of the game is easy to catch, but the simplicity is the beauty when it come the tasks game provides. The monologs from the AI, the unusual in a pristine laboratory setting keeps the interest up until the end with few questions which each player comes up whilst playing.   'Cake is a lie' is a schrodinger's cat dilemma during all the game.  Many thanks goes out to the developers!  Suggest this game to any type of gamer!  -P.S. Portal 2 is an improvement, addition and overall great sequel to the series!

Enough has been said about Portal already, so I can only affirm all the praise this game has been getting for all these years. It's a game with a strong and unique gameplay and story that is built around it, not the other way around. The initial surroundings are sterile and desolate and the occasional glitches in GLaDOS' voice only reinforce the feeling of isolation and things going wrong somewhere behind the scenes. The silent protagonist helps the player enjoy the game as they want, either as a clever puzzle platformer or a deepely emotional experience, the latter being my case and indeed the reason why this game stands out. It also doesn't have the audacity to tell you exactly how to feel about certain situations, presents the game world as it is and can affect in many ways - will you feel desperate? Lonely? Terrified? Amused? Will you chuckle at the dark jokes or be shocked by the borderline horror gallows humor. Much of this is caused by the brilliant GLaDOS. Just let me say this, to kinda sum it up: a game that causes me to grow this attached to a piece of fictional metal with a drawn pink heart on it does something very, very right.
For more information, please attend an Enrichment Center Electrical Safety seminar.

I think I speak for most people when I say that Portal is one of the best games of the past 15 years.  I got this game a few years back when it was free as part of some educational initiatve, and it's proven to be a favorite of mine ever since. Anything I say will pretty much echo what everyone else has said, but this game's praises really do need to be repeated over and over again because it really is that good. The gameplay remains some of the most innovative out there, with unique and fun puzzles that have the perfect balance of challenge and accessibility, and the witty writing always gets a few chuckles out of me. The only con I can think of is that the game is decidedly short, but that is easily made up for by the personality that permeates every single frame.  So, in closing, if you don't already own the game, get it. Like, right now. DO IT!

I just played Portal for the first time, 10 years after its initial release. I've heard how amazing this game is from a few friends, so my expectations were set pretty high, which usually results with me being disappointed. However, Portal lived up to all the hype. The storyline and characters are pretty weak, but that's the only flaw I can find. The graphics are great for a 2007 game and the gameplay is amazing. The concept of solving puzzle rooms may seem mundane, but the intricate physics of the connected portals makes this game one of the funnest games I've ever played. The main storyline serves as an excellent tutorial that gets progressively more difficult and does provide some amusing moments through a subpar storyline. For a real challenge, the game provides bonus maps, wherein I spent majority of my 20 hours of gameplay. Highly recommend for everyone.

7.5/10  Can I have my cake now? ..... no? Ok....  I have to admit, Portal was a blast! The puzzles were fun to solve, and the shift in the story was interesting. Portal is a short but entertaining game, and I loved it.  To start this off, I've got to talk about the puzzles. One of the reasons that I loved this game so much was because of its sometimes frustrating difficulty. The puzzles are physics-based and require a lot of skill regarding spatial problem solving. But, don't worry, the mechanics are easy to pick up, and the game does a great job of easing you into the gameplay. In fact, the tutorial is worked into the first few levels very well, so its not a pain to sit through. Personally, this game was a satisfying mental challenge, especially in the later levels. Mind you, the puzzles can get annoying at times and may take multiple attempts to solve. The biggest piece of advice I can offer with the puzzles is to pay close attention to your surroundings.   (This paragraph is primarily driven by personal taste: my preference is for games with well-written stories, good lore, and strong characters. It doesn't mean I didn't enjoy this game; I was just a little disappointed. If that kind of stuff doesn't matter that much to you in a game, skip the following paragraph.)  In terms of story, Portal is pretty bland. This game's focus is on the puzzle solving and mechanics, which isn't bad. It just gets tiresome. I got bored in the later test chambers and had a hard time enjoying the game until the   fire escape.   Running around Aperture Laboratories did keep me playing, as it added  some  depth to the world of the game. Unfortunately, this lack of story had a negative effect on the final battle. The battle felt obligatory, like the game was scrambling for a climax. The silver lining is that it does a good job of setting the dynamic between GLaDOS and the player in the sequel.   Yes, Portal has its flaws and isn't exactly the best game in the world, but it's still pretty great. It's a well designed game that provides an excellent mental challenge. The story is a bit weak in this one but does a nice job of leading into the story of the second game. Portal, as a series, is excellent, and both games are wonderful in their own right.
